subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized Test Case example
msgSnippet: ... OK, so let me attempt to summarize what I ve learned: Using a parameterized test case that overrides runTest() allows you to vary data without much
messageBody:
On Nov 22, 2003, at 1:45 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> <snip />
>> Along the same lines, I have had occasion to use the same single test
>> method technique with an externalize data file, but allowing for
>> multiple failures to be accumulated. While looping through the "rows"
>> of data, the test method catches AssertionFailedError and adds it to a
>> collection of failures. When the test suite completes, it dumps out
>> any failures that were collected along the way.
>
> Right. The only difference is that I'm letting JUnit play the role of
> "failure collector," since that's what it was designed for. :) :)

OK, so let me attempt to summarize what I've learned:

Using a parameterized test case that overrides runTest() allows you to
vary data without much duplication, report a unique expressive message
for each failed test, and run the suite to completion without bringing
down the whole suite when a test fails.

This isn't the only way to achieve those goals, but it's the most
straightforward way you've found in the spirit of the JUnit design.

How'd I do?

Mike
